To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
, and of her Hig
nes
most honorable privy councell
page.lettertext:
28 June
1585
From M
r
Bodeley
fol.127r
Right honorable, my dutifull affection most humbly premise
d
I hope it is but nedeles, to reherse againe unto yo
r
H. what I
writte from
Hambourgh
, at my first comminge over, & then after
from
Lubecke
, the last of Maye: whiche letter contened the
D. of
Brunswickes
answear, & was sent unto yo
r
H. by one
John Roberts
of
London
, dwellinge by
Bassinges halle
.
The 8 of this present I came to
Coppenhaven
, where I learned
that the
Kinge
, was come newly out of
Norwaye
, & was then at
Elseno
r
. I was no sooner come thither, but the
Treasurer
sent
to knowe, if I came from her
Ma
tie
to the Kinge: & requested w
t
all, that I would staye untill suche time, as I knewe
e Kinges
pleasure: for he would certifie of my comminge. I was there
informed, that the
Chauncello
r
Kaas
was gone into
Funelande
:
wheruppon I writte unto him, sent yo
r
H. letter, signified my
errande, & craved his furtheraunce. Likewise yo
r
letter to
Mon
sr
Dancy
, I delivered my self at Coppenhaven, who sorowed very
muche, for the absence of the Chauncello
r
. W
t
in two daies after, I
had worde from
e Treasurer, that it was the K. pleasure, I
should come to Elseno
r
. Where I came the same daye, and the
morning after was sent for to the castell, to have mine audienc
e
There I founde w
t
the K.
e most of his court, & an
embassado
r
of Norrembergh
.
In the best maner &
e best wordes that I could meditat, I de
livered her Hig
nes
commendac
o
ns, & loving affection, declaringe
her carefulnes to heare of his welfare, & of
e
Quene
his wife,
& all his children: of the peace of his contrey, & of his best co
n
tentat
o
n in all thinges: yelded further her Ma
ties
speciall thank
s
for all his roiall offers, & signes of benevolence, w
t
[profer] of the
like: shewed her infinite desire, to see him in person in her Hig
nes
contrey: that she would like of Englishe grownde, the better while
she lived (whiche were her Ma
ties
wordes) & that she thought it not
so happie w
t
Princes as w
t
others, in that they wanted the ben
e
fitte, to come & goe at their pleasure, & see one an other. How
beit if the voiage were as easie, & convenient for her as for him
it should be one of the first, that she would make, & it had not
bin
to
make
a
great while ago: w
t
other like speeches, as her Ma
tie
fol.127v
willed, & my message required: & then presented my letters of
whiche because so many stoode by, & every one might heare, I did
but explicat in generall, howe muche the argument imported, not
only the dignitie, & good estate of both their Ma
ties
but the publicke
Weale of all protestant Princes, & of every good Christian: & re-
ferred my self for a further & more particular declaration to his
Ma
ties
appointment.
After the reading of the letter, & some conference apart, betwene
e
Kinge & his Chauncello
r
Henry Ramelius, I was presently answea-
red by the Chauncello
r
: who standing by the K. signified his lo
vinge acceptation of her Ma
ties
message, w
t
as great a declara-
tion of thankes, of gladnes, of frindship & good will, as could
be expressed: & howe he promised to consider of my buisnes,
& speede it in suche sort, as the matter required. The K. therw
t
all
tooke me by the hande, & helde me still in talke, untill his diner
was brought in, & then sette me by him at the table. Where after
many questions, & carouses to her Ma
tie
at whiche he gave her
that diner 33 shotte of great artillerie, I tooke occasion to
signifie, that it was her Ma
ties
pleasure I should shewe him, tha
t
every day & almost every meale, she dranke a harty drawg
ht
unto him. And w
t
all, I did renewe that petition of her longinge to
see him, requestinge suche an answear, as when I came into my
contrey, might make me better welcome. It was evident to
see by his countenaunce & cheere, & every waye besides, that he
tooke a great pleasure to be urged so againe, & made me answear,
that as God had appointed, so it should be. But if twentie yeres
ago, there had bin that amitie betwene her Ma
tie
and him, as there
was at this present, this motion at this time, had bin but super-
fluous. Nevertheles to this req
e
st, he would geve no deniall, &
he would be very lothe to be prevented by death, before he had seen
her: whome he solemnly protested, that if it were possible, he loved
better then his wife. With this & other like talke, he dranke so
morely unto me, & that so muche the more, for that in pledging
againe I made it no drinke, to answear to his humo
r
, that the
rest of that daye, was fitte to doe nothinge. There was afte
r
this diner, no other talke in all the court, but of the K. goinge into
Englande: & as I was informed by very credible persons, he ha
d
speeche w
t
sundrie gentlemen about it, & gave it out for certai
ne
fol.128r
he would see the lande before longe: tellinge one amonge the
...
that being come uppon the coast, he would not come a shoare, unl-
es her Ma
tie
were his guide, & would mete him a litle, & bringe
him of the water. Every man thought, that he will take this voi
age on the soddaine, w
t
out giving any notice.
The next morninge the Chauncello
r
came to me to my lodginge, &
tolde me, that he was sent unto me from
e K. to request my rela
tion, of that I had
in
charge: for that the K. could speake no Latin.
Wheruppon I imparted all unto him, the more freely, for that I found
him a man of good understanding, learned, & well affected to the
cause, whiche I was also tolde before by Mons
r
Dancy.
The morowe after, being Sonday, I was invited by the Chauncelo
r
, to
dine w
t
e K. & if I would in like maner, to heare the service in
his chapell. Understanding my willingnes, he returned to
e K. &
came againe w
t
divers gentlemen to conduct me to
e castell, who
signified that the K. had caused his service, to be said in Latin,
at
I might understand it: & so brought me to
e K. who in goinge to
churche, went bareheadded all the waye, & putte me perforce to kepe
the upper hand, sett me w
t
him in his pue, & after at his table, in
the higher place: w
t
other ceremonies of preheminence, both at that
time
&
after, during all my aboade: whiche I would not but write of,
for that I went but as a messenger, &
yet
to manifest to all men, his
affection to her Hig
nes
he was desirous so to use me.
Before diner a litle, I had some talke w
t
e K. as touching my
message, who tolde me w
t
some grief, that his hope was smalle of
good successe: but yet
e fault should be any mans rather then his:
& promised to kepe me, but a daye or two longer.
All dinner time, whiche continued six houres, the chiefest part of
his talke was of her Ma
tie
her court, & affaires. He had heard a
litle inkling of
Parrey
, but w
t
out any circumstaunce: whiche
he
desired me to tell him, & was mervelously moved, to heare the par
ticulars. The next
daie
after I sent him
e booke, w
c
by chaunce I
had w
t
me, & he sette it in hande, to be presently translated.
Uppon demaundes that he had made, of
e
Scottishe Queenes
practises,
he
asked me a reason, why her Ma
tie
proceeded no shaplier against he
r
Whiche I tolde him I thought was consanguinitie, & for that she ha
d
bin a Quene, & her Ma
ties
inclination was more to mercy, then to ri
gour. Wherto he replied, that those were good causes, if the partie
would be quiet, & had committed no suche crimes. But the case
well considered, he wished that her Ma
tie
would respect her owne safeti
e
fol.128v
& live a life w
t
out feare. For
if
the other had her Ma
tie
as
e like advan-
tage, she should quickly feele the smart. I will not holde yo
r
H.
w
t
report of all that was talked of, not carieng any specaltie, but
lette it stande untill my returne.
The better part of
e next day he bestowed in counsail, about
her Ma
ties
requestes: & the morowe after I was sent for & shewed
all the castell: where in a chamber of
e Kinge, the Chauncelo
r
&
e captaine of
e castell, brought his answear to her Ma
tie
whiche
his letter conteneth in generall maner, but
e Chauncelo
r
by
words
declared more in particular: w
t
all suche complements at first,
as they are wonte to dilate: but protesting in speciall that
e K.
did muche rejoice to see her Ma
ties
religious stedfastnes in urging
this association of Princes: whiche he thought it be so necessarie, as
nothing more, & yet hitherto of some, so litle respected, that it
putte him cleane out of hope, of doinge any good. And therfore he
for his owne part, was resolved longe agoe, to lette it alone as a
desperat cause, to give him self to quietnes, to defende his owne
contreis, & to put his c
o
fidence in God, for preserving of his
churche. All whiche notw
t
standing, for her Ma
ties
sake, who
might cause
him
to doe any thinge, he would once againe, though it
were w
t
litle hope, sette in foote & doe his best in every point,
as her Ma
tie
desired, if other Princes would joine w
t
him:
making answear to particulars, as
e D. of Brunswicke: but that
he promised besides, to send her Ma
ties
letter to
e
D. of Holst
.
For it came to my handes w
t
out any instruction, & I knewe no better
waye, then to praye
e K. to sende it: whiche he was willing to doe
& to sende it w
t
his owne, w
t
in 3 or 4 daies: & to write w
t
all
to
e
Electors
,
Lantgrave of Hesse
,
e D. of
Pomerane
, &
Mechel
bourgh
&
e rest.
Moreover for that I had informed him of
e
D. of Lorraine
, w
c
I sig-
nified yo
r
H. was desirous he should knowe, he hath written
unto yo
w
a letter of thankes, w
c
I will bringe when I come, w
t
his
letter to her Ma
tie
.
Being thus dismissed
e 16 of this moneth, he sent divers of his
gentlemen, to kepe my company to Coppenhaven, & from thence appoin-
ted two guides, to conduct me to Hambourgh, through
e land of
Holst
, whiche is 10 daies jorney from Elseno
r
: to provide me of
coches & necessaries, to shew me by the waye, all his castels &
houses: whiche kinde of intertenment w
t
e rest, preferred a
poore Messenger to an Embassado
rs
Charge. The passage
from Coppenhaven to Lubecke by sea, had bin
surer
spedier, if the
winde
fol.129r
had served, as it serveth very seldome, at this time of
e yeere,
...
I am from hence to goe to Brunswicke, as the D. did appoint me,
to
take
e Electo
r
s answears, w
c
every man feares will be to small pur
pose: & so muche
e more, for that
e
D. of Saxonie
faileth in memorie
& is otherwise sickly: by meanes wherof, it is thought of some, that
the
Duchesse
his wife, no frinde to this cause, will ether beare a
great swaye in framinge
e answear, or alleaging his infirmitie
or
make no answear at all. But thoughe
e principall intent doe not
chaunce to take place, yet I trust it is obtened, that no souldier
hereafter, shall goe from hence to
e ennemie. For I am done to
witte, that
e D. of Holst, &
e D. of Mechelbourgh, have written
to Lubecke, to see that no souldiers be levied among them: Whiche
proceedes I thinke from
e
Administrato
r
of Halles
, &
e D. of
Brunswicke, as principall persons of autoritie, in
e diet of
lowe
Saxonie
.
Mons
r
Dancy, whose letter to yo
r
H. I bringe w
t
the rest, is of opini
on, that unles the difference, that is betwene us & these contreis, in
pointes of religion, be first of all composed, there wilbe no conjunction
in these other deseignes. This composition he thinkes might be
mervelous easie: as he himself will shewe howe, in a treatise of hi
s
owne, whiche he hath made for that purpose: & hath promised shortly
to send me a copie. We are wrongfully charged w
t
many
false opinions: whiche he hath specified the meanes, to cause these
Princes to perceave, if they would geve as but
e hearinge. Wherupp
on
it is his counsail, that when her Ma
tie
sendeth any, there maye be sen
t
along w
t
him, some learned divines, who may desire to have confer
ence
to purge o
r
Churche of those opinions, whiche are fathered on it so u
n
truly. This maner of proceeding he is thorowly persuaded, will we
...
a good alteration in the mindes of these Princes. Of this I knowe
not if his letter doe make any mention, but he requested me earnest
ly
to breake it to yo
r
H. And if
Mons
r
Segurius
had taken that cou
rse
the time was very
good
fitte
, & happely some good might then have en-
sewed: as there maye aswell hereafter, where it shalbe putte in
practise. But the circumstances weighed of the time as it is, there
is no hope by this meanes, to serve the present necessitie. For fir
st
it wilbe longe, before men can be chosen, & brought to meete of both
sides. And then when they meete, it is in Vaine to expect, that o
...
uppon
e soddaine will yelde unto an other. The good must co
m
after when God hath appointed, though perhaps in some mens har
ts
somwhat presently refourmed. But Princes commonly rely
uppon
e learning of their clarkes, & we see it so w
t
clarkes, th
at
if they be of reputation, having deepely once conceaved an er
o
neous impression, although they could be contented, when they see
fol.129v
what is amisse, to admitte an
adm
amendement, yet at suche a time
of expectation, & in causes of conscience, they will stand in all
likelyhoode, uppon
e same of their constantie, their credit w
t
their
Princes, &
e opinion of their Learning. And Learning, it is evi-
dent, never wanteth shifting reasons to maintene absurd opinions.
This by common experience, is founde to be the maner, unles God
of his goodnes, use an extraordinarie workinge. So that this kinde
of plotte, requiring so muche time, &
e cause that is in hand, so
great expedition, I see no hope it doth offer, of obteninge that
is sought.
The consideration herof appertening to yo
r
H. I leave it as a
motion made by Mons
r
Dancy: Whose pietie & forwardnes
to advaunce the common cause, is not Unknowen to yo
r
H. & to
me in particular, his counsail & cowrtesie was wanting in nothing.
He hath bin lately in hande w
t
e K. of Denmarke, & wilbe so
againe, to send an embassado
r
to
e
Frenche K.
to persuade him
in any wise, not to putte up this injurie.
It is tolde me heere in Hambourgh, that
e D. of Saxonie, & his sonne
the
Marchese of Brandeburgh
,
e D. of Brunsw
.
e Administrator
of Hales & others, meete very shortly in
sylva Garlebiensi
, to con-
sult of some matters of speciall importaunce: but of what there
is no speeche: wheruppon I conjecture, there wilbe somwhat conclu-
ded, about these affaires of my message. I am further informed
by a principall person, that if
e K. of Denmarke holde his deseig
ne
he wilbe one at that meetinge. Howbeit of the D. of Saxo-
nies comminge, there is no kinde of certaintie, by reason of his mala
die, whiche as I understande, is
e falling sicknes; whiche taketh
him as often, as any matter of weight, that trobleth his minde is
proposed unto him: & bereveth him of memorie, & common use of
reason. So that for the most part, those that are of his counsel
who are distracted in these matters, have the maneging of all thinges.
If the D. of Brunsw
.
according to his promise, in the diet of Lowe
Saxonie, whiche I mentioned in my last, will move the Princes of
that meeting, to doe somwhat in this cause, I hope that example,
will move other Princes, that it maye be a steppe to a great deale of
good. The principal matter that shalbe handled in that circle, is
as I have had intelligence, to take order for clearing the river of Em
s
that
e course of traffique maye be free: & to lette
e Spaniard of
his purpose, whose preparation they feare; lest it tende in some p
ar
t
to
fol.130r
to take possession of that river.
It is heere affirmed for certaine, that
e
sonne
of Adolphe
D. of Holst is elected Bishop of Breame: whose competito
r
s have bin
the
Bishop of Halberstat
, &
e eldest
sonne
of
William D. of Lu-
nebourgh
.
I have notice given me, of an answear framed to
e
K. of Na-
varra
, by some certaine of those Princes, but caried too & fro, & not
concluded by them all,
that
whiche tendeth to this purpose, that
e
booke of Concorde, shalbe sent to
e K. & he requested to signifie
what he chiefly misliketh: whiche they are willing to debate, by
conference of divines, deputed on both sides. This I feare, if it be
true, will prove an endles piece of worke, occupie the time, and
come to no good passe.
Which I should have signified before, there was a talke at Coppen-
haven of a coache & six horses, whiche the Kinge hath in readines,
& is
present
purposed shortly, to present to her Ma
tie
.
M
r
Harbert
& I have bin publickly feasted in this towne, w
t
great
solemnitie & respect.
As by yo
r
honorable favo
r
, alwaies very speciall, & on my
part undeserved, I have obtened the credit, to be imploied in this
service, so I am to crave w
t
all humblenes & instaunce, whatsoever
I have done ether ignorantly or defectively, or otherwise then should
be, it may please yo
r
H. to protest it w
t
a favorable construction
Wherwith I take my humble leave, beseching God continually to
blesse yo
r
H. welfare, yo
r
estate & affaires with all maner
of prosperitie. Hambourgh. 1585. Junij: 28 Yo
r
H most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
By the advise of an honest gentleman one
Vitus
Winsemius
, a man of good reputation & zele in religion,
& in very good favo
r
w
t
e K. of Denmarke, &
e D. of Holst,
whome he serveth both, as their deputie in the next circle
of Lowe Saxonie, I am persuaded for my safetie, whiche for
divers respectes, he wisheth me to looke unto, to leave the
common way that leadeth to Brunswicke, & to take an
other course by
Duke Otto of Lunebourgh
her Ma
ties
Pensioner,
whome I am promised to finde a speciall frinde unto my
buisnes, if I salute him by the waye.
I knowe not howe yo
r
H. can like
e bacon of this
country, but I have sent yow certaine gammons, w
c
I was carefull should be good, & have taken order w
t
a frinde, to see them delivered: though nether he, nor
any man els can deliver my affection, & most
serviceable minde at yo
r
H. disposition.
